abstracts.cdata!:
The Fertilizer Sector Loan Project for
            Yugoslavia was approved by the board on May 8, 1984 and
            again, in revised form, in 1985. It was never signed, and
            the Bank withdrew its offer on July 31, 1986. Following
            appraisal, there was disagreement over the Bank's
            analysis and recommendation to channel a large portion of
            the incremental fertilizer production to individual farmers
            not contractually associated with the social sector. The
            Government made clear the fact that the Bank's
            proposals were in opposition to the stated policy of
            socializing agricultural production. A compromise was
            reached, and this report lists the several policy
            conditions. Following protracted discussions, the Government
            reluctantly agreed that most of the resulting incremental
            fertilizer production as a result of the project would be
            offered in sale to independent farmers rather than reserved
            for the socialist sector. However, this very agreement
            greatly reduced the Government's zeal for finding
            solutions to the other basic loan issues. After the second
            Board approval, the Government proved unwilling to implement
            procedure that would have assured adequate foreign exchange
            to meet the future import needs of the fertilizer industry.
            Still, this report finds that he project was sound and the
            potential payoff in improved resource allocation and
            increased agriculture production was impressive. Ultimately,
            despite monumental efforts at many levels, the disagreements
            on policy issues between the Bank and the Government
            prevented this loan from being signed. The report finds that
            the Bank was absolutely correct to withdraw support for the
            loan. The project is not rated and will not be audited.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fertilizer Sector Loan Project will
            be made under the Special Action Program for Yugoslavia and
            will assist the Federal Government in increasing the
            availability of finished fertilizer for 1984 and 1985. It
            will also address policy and institutional issues concerning
            distribution of fertilizer and the Government's efforts
            to modernize and rehabilitate the industry, thereby
            enhancing the Government's on-going Fertilizer
            Production-Consumption program. The loan will: (a) finance
            sub-loans to fertilizer producers for the: (i) import of raw
            materials, such as phosphate rock, mono-ammonium phosphate;
            and (ii) import of spare parts for fertilizer production
            facilities, such as corrosion resistant materials, stainless
            steel piping and catalysts for ammonia production; and (b)
            finance sub-loans to fertilizer producers for technical and
            energy studies of all the fertilizer plants, with the
            assistance of consultants, in order to assess their
            production and energy efficiency and to make proposals for improvements.
